definition[0]: expecting people to obey rules or to do what you say
example[1]: This company is very strict about punctuality.
example[2]: The Stuarts are very strict with their children.
definition[1]: a strict order or rule is one that must be obeyed
example[3]: You had strict instructions not to tell anybody.
example[4]: There are strict limits on presidential campaign contributions.
example[5]: He’s under strict orders from his doctor to quit smoking.
example[6]: I’m telling you this in the strictest confidence (=it must be kept completely secret).
definition[2]: exact and correct, often in a way that seems unreasonable
example[7]: Amy was attractive, although not beautiful in the strictest sense of the word.
definition[3]: obeying all the rules of a religion or set of principles
example[8]: He was raised a strict Catholic.
heading[0]: – Meaning 2: a strict order or rule is one that must be obeyed
example[10]: There are strict rules and regulations regarding conduct.
example[11]: The club has a strict dress code.
example[12]: Doctors have a strict code of conduct.
example[13]: Many airlines impose strict limits on the weight of baggage.
example[14]: He’s left strict instructions not to be disturbed.
example[15]: There must be strict control of local government spending.
example[16]: The head teacher insists upon strict discipline throughout the school.
example[17]: Landlords must comply with strict safety requirements.
example[18]: The supermarket’s suppliers must meet strict criteria.
example[19]: He went on a strict diet and lost a lot of weight.
collocation[9]: in strict confidence/in the strictest confidence
example[20]: Any information you give will be treated in the strictest confidence.
definition[4]: expecting people to obey rules or to do what you say – used especially about parents, teachers, or organizations
example[22]: Most schools are quite strict about the way students dress.
definition[5]: showing that you are in control of the situation and will not change your opinion, especially when you are telling someone what to do
example[23]: You have to be firm with young children.
example[24]: I’ll be firm with him and tell him he can’t have any more money.
definition[6]: determined that your orders or decisions will be obeyed, especially in order to make sure that a situation improves – used especially when you think that someone is right to be strict
example[25]: We need a government that is tough on crime.
example[26]: She can be quite tough with her students, but they respect her for it.
example[27]: The chancellor has got to be tough and keep government spending down.
definition[7]: strict in a serious, disapproving, and rather unfriendly way
example[28]: Her grandfather was a stern man who rarely smiled.
example[29]: Sheila walked into the museum, under the stern gaze of the curator.
definition[8]: punishing or criticizing someone in a way that seems very severe, often too severe
example[30]: Don’t be too harsh on her – she’s only a child.
example[31]: It may seem harsh to punish him, but he has to learn that this kind of behaviour is unacceptable.
example[32]: Her reaction to the child’s bad behaviour was unnecessarily harsh.
definition[9]: very strict about forcing people to obey rules or laws, and punishing them very severely if they fail to do this – used about people and governments
example[33]: Her father was very authoritarian and insisted on total obedience.
example[35]: There are strict rules about keeping tax records.
example[36]: He had strict instructions to return the key to me.
definition[10]: tight  controls or limits are very strict about what is allowed and what is not allowed
example[37]: The report recommends tighter controls on the advertising of alcohol.
example[38]: There are tight regulations governing waste disposal.
definition[11]: tough laws or rules are very strict
example[39]: They want tougher laws against drinking and driving.
example[40]: The federal government is introducing tough new rules on immigration.
definition[12]: harsh punishments or laws are very severe, often too severe
example[41]: There are harsh penalties for drug trafficking.
example[42]: The government has brought in harsh measures to combat the rioting taking place in many cities.
definition[13]: controlling what people can do with rules that have very high standards
example[43]: There are now stringent controls on pollution from all power stations.
